subsection.title: Geometric length of a vector: the norm
subsection.p: We can easily determine the length of a vector in the plane from its components using the Pythagorean Theorem.

image.description: Using Pythagoras to determine the length of a vector.

subsection.p: If we let \ell represent the length of \uvec{v}, then Pythagoras tells us that \ell^2 = (\Delta x)^2 + (\Delta y)^2.

aside.title: Remember
aside.p: There is no such operation as squaring a vector, so it would be incorrect to write \uvec{v}^2 = (\Delta x)^2 + (\Delta y)^2.

subsection.p: We write \unorm{v} to mean the length of the vector \uvec{v} in the plane. Keep in mind in all that follows that \unorm{v} is always a single number, since it measures a length. If \uvec{v} has components \uvec{v} = (v_1,v_2) (where v_1 = \Delta x and v_2 = \Delta y), then solving for \ell in the Pythagorean equation above gives us \unorm{v} = \sqrt{v_1^2 + v_2^2}.
For a vector \uvec{v} = (v_1,v_2,v_3) in \R^3, consider the vector \uvec{v}' = (v_1,v_2,0) sitting in the xy-plane.

image.description: Using Pythagoras to determine the length of a vector.

subsection.p: Applying the Pythagorean Theorem to the vertical triangle, we find \unorm{v}^2 = \norm{\uvec{v}'}^2 + (\Delta z)^2. But \uvec{v}' lies flat in the xy-plane, and we have already analyzed that case above: \norm{\uvec{v}'}^2 = (\Delta x)^2 + (\Delta y)^2. Combining these, we get \unorm{v}^2 = \bbrac{(\Delta x)^2 + (\Delta y)^2} + (\Delta z)^2 = v_1^2 + v_2^2 + v_3^2, so that \unorm{v} = \sqrt{v_1^2 + v_2^2 + v_3^2}.

The word length ceases to have any meaning in \R^4, so in general we refer to \unorm{v} as the norm of \uvec{v} in any dimension. We imagine that if we were able to somehow measure length in \R^n for n\ge 4, then the pattern where we used length in \R^2 to help us compute length in \R^3 would be repeated, and we would be able to use length in \R^3 to help us compute length in \R^4, and then we would be able to use length in \R^4 to help us compute length in \R^5, and so on. So it seems reasonable to define the norm of a vector \uvec{v} = (v_1,v_2,\dotsc,v_n) in \R^n to be \unorm{v} = \sqrt{v_1^2 + v_2^2 + \dotsb + v_n^2}. Square roots are annoying to work with algebraically, so we often work with the square of a norm, for which we developed the formula \unorm{v}^2 = v_1^2 + v_2^2 + \dotsb + v_n^2. in .

subsection.title: Properties of the norm
subsection.p: We explored some other basic properties of the norm in . First, when we take the square root of a nonzero number, we always take the positive square root, so a norm is never a negative number. This property agrees with our conception of norm as a length in \R^2 and \R^3, since in geometry we usually require lengths to be nonnegative.

Second, the zero vector \zerovec = (0,0,\dotsc,0) always has norm 0 in every dimension, since \norm{\zerovec} = \sqrt{0^2 + 0^2 + \dotsb + 0^2} = \sqrt{0} = 0. And it is the only vector that has norm 0, since as soon as one of the components of a vector is nonzero, the sum of squares under the square root sign in the norm formula will be a positive number. There is no possibility of cancellation to zero under the square root, even if a vector has a mix of positive and negative components, because squaring the components will always have positive results.

Finally, we considered the effect of a scalar multiplication on norm. Geometrically, in \R^2 and \R^3 we think of scalar multiplication as scaling a vector's length by some scale factor k, so we should expect the numerical norm of a vector to be multiplied by the scale factor. And that is (almost) exactly what happens:
\unorm{v} \amp= \sqrt{v_1^2 + v_2^2 + \dotsb + v_n^2}, \amp \norm{k\uvec{v}} \amp= \sqrt{(kv_1)^2 + (kv_2)^2 + \dotsb + (kv_n)^2} \\ \amp\amp \amp= \sqrt{k^2v_1^2 + k^2v_2^2 + \dotsb + k^2v_n^2} \\ \amp\amp \amp= \sqrt{k^2(v_1^2 + v_2^2 + \dotsb + v_n^2)} \\ \amp\amp \amp= \sqrt{k^2}\sqrt{v_1^2 + v_2^2 + \dotsb + v_n^2} \\ \amp\amp \amp= \sqrt{k^2}\unorm{v}.
We need to be a little careful with the last step, because it is not always true that \sqrt{k^2} = k. In particular, the result of \sqrt{k^2} is never negative, so if k is negative then it is impossible for \sqrt{k^2} to be equal to k. The proper formula for all values of k is \sqrt{k^2} = \abs{k}, so our norm formula becomes \norm{k\uvec{v}} = \abs{k}\unorm{v}.

subsection.title: Unit vectors and normalization
subsection.p: In the plane or in space, a vector with length 1 is convenient geometrically because it can be used as a metre stick every scalar multiple of that vector will have length equal to the (absolute value of) the scale factor. For example, if \uvec{u} has length 1, then both 3\uvec{u} and -3\uvec{u} have length 3. The same pattern will hold in any dimension when we replace the word length with norm. A vector with norm 1 is called a unit vector. One of the reasons the standard basis vectors are so special is that each of them is a unit vector, as we saw in . Thus each standard basis vector can be used as a metre stick along the corresponding axis.

aside.title: Remember
aside.p: We should never divide by a vector because there is no such vector operation (see ). But \unorm{v} is a number, not a vector, so k = \frac{1}{\unorm{v}} is valid.

subsection.title: Distance between vectors
subsection.p: As we saw in , if we think of \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} as sharing the same initial points, then the difference vectors \uvec{u}-\uvec{v} and \uvec{v}-\uvec{u} run between the terminal points of \uvec{u} and \uvec{v}.

So we can measure the distance between the terminal points of \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} by computing \norm{\uvec{u}-\uvec{v}} or \norm{\uvec{v}-\uvec{u}}, as we discovered in . This process is even more straightforward when the common initial point of \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} is chosen to be the origin, so that the components of \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} are the same as the coordinates of their respective terminal points.

remark.p: The analysis above uses a useful strategy to compute distances in the plane or in space: determine some vector that traverses the distance in question, and then compute the norm of that vector to obtain the desired distance. Combined with some of the vector geometry that we will develop in the next few chapters, this strategy is often easier than trying to determine the coordinates of the points at the endpoints of the desired distance. You should remember this strategy when we explore the geometry of lines and planes in Chapters.

subsection.title: Angle between vectors in the plane and in space
subsection.p: Two vectors in the plane, when given the same initial point, have two angles between them.

image.description: Diagram of the angles between two vectors in the plane.

subsection.p: We only need to know one of these two angles, since the other can be computed from the knowledge that the sum of the two angles is 2\pi radians. We generally prefer to avoid ambiguity in math, so it would be nice to have a systematic way to choose one of the two angles between a pair of vectors that we can refer to as the angle between the vectors. We will not distinguish between clockwise and counterclockwise, because those terms will become meaningless when we move up a dimension. Instead we will always choose the smaller angle to be the angle between the two vectors.

image.description: Diagram illustrating the preference of the interior angle between two vectors in the plane.

subsection.p: Thus, the angle between two vectors in the plane will always be between 0 and \pi radians. Note that it is possible for the angle to be exactly 0 radians or exactly \pi radians, in the case the the two vectors are parallel.

image.description: Diagram of the angles between parallel vectors in the plane.

subsection.p: In space, two vectors that are positioned to share the same initial point can be completed to a triangle, and that triangle will lie in a plane. The angle between the two vectors can then be taken to be the smaller of the two angles between the two vectors in that shared plane.

figure.caption: Diagram of the angle between vectors in space, embedded in a plane

image.description: Diagram of the angle between vectors in space.

aside.p: In this diagram, you should imagine the shaded surface passing through the origin, with the two vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} lying flat in it.

subsection.title: Dot product
subsection.p: In , we combined vector geometry with some high school geometry to determine a formula for the (cosine of the) angle between two plane vectors. Recall from that a vector that runs between the terminal points of two vectors that share an initial point is a difference vector.

image.description: Diagram of the law of cosines applied to a triangle of vectors.

subsection.p:
The lengths of the sides of the triangle formed by these three vectors are just the norms of the vectors:
a \amp= \unorm{u}, \amp b \amp= \unorm{v}, \amp c \amp= \norm{\uvec{u}-\uvec{v}}.
The Law of Cosines applied to this triangle says that a^2+b^2-c^2 = 2ab\cos\theta.

aside.p: It would be nonsense to write this as \uvec{u}^2+\uvec{v}^2-(\uvec{u}-\uvec{v})^2 = 2\uvec{u}\uvec{v}cos\theta, because there are no such operations as multiplying or squaring vectors.

subsection.p:
Let's give our plane vectors some components so that we can work with this equality:
\uvec{u} \amp= (u_1,u_2), \amp \uvec{v} \amp= (v_1,v_2), \amp \uvec{u}-\uvec{v} \amp= (u_1-v_1,u_2-v_2).
Now we have
a^2 \amp= \unorm{u}^2 \amp b^2 \amp= \unorm{v}^2 \amp c^2 \amp= \norm{\uvec{u}-\uvec{v}}^2 \\ \amp= u_1^2+u_2^2, \amp \amp= v_1^2 + v_2^2, \amp \amp= (u_1-v_1)^2 + (u_2-v_2)^2 \\ \amp\amp\amp\amp \amp= u_1^2 - 2u_1v_1 + v_1^2 + u_2^2 - 2u_2v_2 + v_2^2,
and so after some cancelling we have a^2 + b^2 - c^2 = 2u_1v_1 + 2u_2v_2. Using the expression on the right above for the left-hand side of the equality a^2+b^2-c^2 = 2ab\cos\theta for \cos\theta, solving for \cos\theta, and then substituting a=\unorm{u} and b=\unorm{v} leads to
\cos\theta = \frac{u_1v_1 + u_2v_2}{\unorm{u}\unorm{v}}.
The expression on the left and the denominator on the right are both familiar we have the ordinary cosine function from trigonometry and we have some vector norms. However, before we worked through , the expression in the numerator on the right-hand side was unknown.

Earlier in this chapter, we mentioned how two vectors in space with their initial points at the origin lie inside a common flat plane (see ). If we repeated the above geometric analysis of vector angle in this flat surface inside space, we would come to a similar conclusion:
\cos\theta = \frac{u_1v_1 + u_2v_2 + u_3v_3}{\unorm{u}\unorm{v}}.
There is an obvious pattern to the numerators on the right-hand sides of equations
and . And it seems that the number that these numerator formulas compute is important, since it provides a link between the two most important quantities in geometry: length and angle. So we give it a name, the dot product (or the Euclidean inner product), and use the symbol \dotprod{}{} between two vectors to represent this quantity. The formula can obviously be extended to higher dimensions than just the plane \R^2 and space \R^3, so we will do just that: \udotprod{u}{v} = u_1v_1 + u_2v_2 + \dotsb + u_n v_n.

warning.p:
The result of the computation \udotprod{u}{v} is a number, which is important to keep in mind if you are working algebraically with an expression containing a dot product. See
in
for algebraic rules involving the dot product.

subsection.title: Angle between vectors in \R^n
subsection.p: Even though we can't see geometry in \R^n for n>3, we have already seen that we can perform computations related to geometry in these spaces. We can attach the number \unorm{v} to a vector \uvec{v} in \R^n that can be interpreted as its length. And for two vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} in \R^n, we can compute the number \udotprod{u}{v} that is somehow related to the geometric relationship between \uvec{u} and \uvec{v}. We have seen that in the plane and in space, \udotprod{u}{v} links that lengths of \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} to the angle between them. But do higher-dimensional vectors have angles between them? Is there some number that we can attach to \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} that measures the angle between them, even if we can't see or measure this angle directly?

The equalities in
and
suggest a pattern we can copy into \R^n in general. We define the angle between \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} to be the unique angle \theta, between 0 and \pi, that makes
\cos\theta \qquad \text{and} \qquad \frac{\udotprod{u}{v}}{\unorm{u}\unorm{v}}
equal.

ul.li:
For every pair of vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} in \R^n, can we always determine a suitable angle \theta in the domain 0\le\theta\le\pi that works ( that makes the two quantities in
equal)?
For some pair of vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} in \R^n, might it be possible that there are several values of \theta in the domain 0\le\theta\le\pi that work?

subsection.p: Fortunately, for a pair of (nonzero) plane vectors or space vectors, there is exactly one number (once we restrict to the domain 0\le\theta\pi) that gets to call itself the angle between the vectors. It would not bode well for the possibility of somehow doing geometry in higher-dimensional spaces if there were sometimes two numbers that could be reasonably called the angle between a pair of vectors, or sometimes none at all. Luckily neither of these is possible.

aside.title: Note
aside.p: The inequality part of the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality is usually stated as \abs{\udotprod{u}{v}} \le \unorm{u}\unorm{v}, which for nonzero vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} is equivalent to -1 \le \frac{\udotprod{u}{v}}{\unorm{u}\unorm{v}} \le 1.

subsection.p: Since the graph y=\cos\theta passes through every possible y-value in the range -1 \le y \le 1, and does so only once, equation always has one unique solution for a pair of nonzero vectors.

subsection.title: Dot product versus norm
subsection.p:
We have already seen that the dot product is intimately tied to the geometry of \R^n, acting as a link between norm (length) and angle. But as we discovered in , it is also directly linked to the norm by the observation
\unorm{v}^2 \amp= (\sqrt{v_1^2 + v_2^2 + \dotsb v_n^2})^2 \amp \udotprod{v}{v} \amp= v_1v_1 + v_2v_2 + \dotsb + v_n v_n \\ \amp= v_1^2 + v_2^2 + \dotsb v_n^2, \amp \amp= v_1^2 + v_2^2 + \dotsb v_n^2.
So we obtain a very convenient formula: \unorm{v}^2 = \udotprod{v}{v}.

subsection.title: Dot product as matrix multiplication
subsection.p:
The pattern in the formula for the dot product of two vectors should look vaguely familiar to you it is a sum of products, which is exactly the pattern of the left-hand side of a linear equation, and so also the pattern in our row-times-column view of matrix multiplication in . In fact, the dot product can be defined in terms of matrix multiplication if we take our vectors to be column vectors and use the transpose to turn one of the columns into a row. Indeed, for
\uvec{u} \amp= \begin{bmatrix}u_1\\u_2\\\vdots\\u_n\end{bmatrix}, \amp \uvec{v} \amp= \begin{bmatrix}v_1\\v_2\\\vdots\\v_n\end{bmatrix},
we have
\utrans{\uvec{v}}\uvec{u} \amp= \begin{bmatrix}v_1 \amp v_2 \amp \cdots \amp v_n\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}u_1\\u_2\\\vdots\\u_n\end{bmatrix}
\amp= v_1 u_1 + v_2 u_2 + \dotsb v_n u_n.
\amp= u_1 v_1 + u_2 v_2 + \dotsb u_n v_n.
\amp= \udotprod{u}{v}.
So we obtain a matrix formula for dot product: \udotprod{u}{v} = \utrans{\uvec{v}}\uvec{u}.

ul.li: Technically, the result of multiplying the 1\times n matrix \utrans{\uvec{v}} and the n\times 1 matrix \uvec{u} should be a 1\times 1 matrix. But algebraically there is no difference between numbers and 1\times 1 matrices with respect to the operations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication, so it is common to think of a 1\times 1 matrix as just a number, as we did above.
